{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3234583,"name":"Learoy","username":"Learoy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/learoy/{size}/176555_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-24T00:58:59.797Z","cooked":"

Greetings to everyone!

My team and I are trying to reduce the impact of logging on the utilization of the CAN bus, one of our research approaches is to understand whether the communication style between the RoboRio and the other robot controllers is “pull” or “receive”.

The difference between the two communication styles is that - Pulling: actively requesting or querying information from other devices on the CAN bus. A device can send a “pull” message to another device, asking for specific data or status updates. This is a way to actively retrieve information from a CAN bus node. Receiving, on the other hand, refers to passively listening for messages on the CAN bus. Devices are constantly monitoring the bus for incoming messages, and when a message with the appropriate identifier (ID) is detected, the device receives and processes that message. This is how devices on the CAN bus passively gather data or commands from other devices without actively requesting it.

We would be very grateful for the clarification about the communication style.
Thanks in advance,
Learoy,
BumbleB 3339

Generally, all can devices always periodically send their control or status packets, and then any device can chose to do something with those packets. Some devices use RTR frames for configuration, but that generally is only during init and not during runtime.

What’s RTR in this case?

Remote Transmission Request, see:

en.wikipedia.org

CAN bus | Remote frame

1.Generally data transmission is performed on an autonomous basis with the data source node (e.g., a sensor) sending out a data frame. It is also possible, however, for a destination node to request the data from the source by sending a remote frame. | 2.There are two differences between a data frame and a remote frame. Firstly the RTR-bit is transmitted as a dominant bit in the data frame and secondly in the remote frame there is no data field. The DLC field indicates the data length of the req...

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-09-24T05:24:56.855Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":125,"readers_count":124,"score":75.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":441365,"topic_slug":"communication-style-between-the-roborio-and-the-robot-controllers-pull-or-receive","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAN_bus#Remote_frame","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CAN bus - Wikipedia","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":25951,"username":"Technologyman00","name":"Technologyman00","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/technologyman00/{size}/178178_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/communication-style-between-the-roborio-and-the-robot-controllers-pull-or-receive/441365/4","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3234703,"name":"Gavin Matthews","username":"bovlb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bovlb/{size}/167232_2.png","created_at":"2023-09-24T18:01:48.593Z","cooked":"

As @Thad_House and @Peter_Johnson explained, methods that draw information from CAN bus devices may either deliver cached results (from periodic status frames) or may send out a request and wait for a response. It is my experience that it is never documented which is which.

From observation, some methods are fast and it is safe to call them liberally in periodic/execute methods, whereas others may cause arbitrary delays and using them in event loop methods tends to lead to loop overruns. It is difficult to say for certain, but I suspect the latter are the ones waiting for a response. It’s also possible that they are just encountering lock contention.

Some insight can be gained by studying the status frame documentation (SparkMAX, Phoenix) and trying to deduce which methods are supported by their fields.

My team and I will experiment with the CAN data analyzer, I will update later on the communication styles according to different functions.
Learoy.
